Author: Crusty_Musty_Fudge

Comment: Trump calling the Canada border an "artificial line" misses the point: all human systems are abstract constructs, but that doesn't make them meaningless. Borders, laws, money, even time zones all don't exist in nature. They're collective hallucinations we enforce through agreement or coercion.  The Louisiana Purchase or the 49th parallel aren't "natural," but they're rooted in treaties and wars. Same with property lines. Your neighbor's yard isn't a law of physics, but try building a pool there. These fictions matter because we've built entire civilizations atop them.  What's wild is how violently we defend these ideas. The Pig War (shoutout to longtermattention) nearly sparked a conflict because two nations couldn't agree on... a pig and a squiggle on a map. Meanwhile, laws that are also equally intangible dictate who gets punished or praised.  Trump's rant feels ironic coming from a guy whose brand is a golden monument to artificiality. But it's a reminder: dismantling constructs requires more than hot air. If borders are arbitrary, why do we gatekeep immigration so brutally? If laws are imaginary, why do they crush some and uplift others?  These systems aren't "fake"-they're tools. The question isn't whether they're artificial, but who benefits from them.
